Or if you wanted fresh meat, you can get fresh chicken , goat, lamb, rabbit. Or even live chickens and ducks if that's your thing. I love the butcher that is located there. As well as the coffee and tea shop. You can just feel the history of the place . To know the people have traded goods there for over 100 years.
review.author: Jason H.

review.description:
I have always had a love for open air markets, even when the weather is bad. This day, it happened to be the case. It was our first weekend back in town (I should state my first time period). I have always been drawn to these types of markets since I visited Pikes Place Market. 

This was a nifty little market, even though we managed to get there pretty late in the day and it was the day of the big bad storm of the season. You know the one that everyone is still talking about, the caused a lot of hail damage. Yeah that's the one! So I probably did not see it at it's best. 

However, with that being said, when you walked into it, in the center. All I could smell was curry. Yummmm. I did love the prices and some of the vendors. We did not pick up anything to take because we had a few places to go. I like it and cannot wait to see it really bustling in better weather.
review.author: Becky M.

review.description:
Ok. So here's the deal. I like people. I mean... I really, really like people. I really, really hate crowds though. So I avoid anytime after 9 on Saturday at Soulard. Some things you should know about the market:

*The earlier you go, the better the produce (duh)
*About half of these marketers are reselling grocery-store produce. Look around at everyone's merchandise before you buy. 
*Some vendors accept credit cards. Most don't. Bring cash.
*I find the best merchants on the lower right leg of the H. 
*Do NOT bring your small children here. It can be a long walk, and there can be spontaneously thick crowds. 
*You will save a ton of money on your produce, and it is far better quality.
*You will save a ton of money on meat, and it is far better quality.
*You will NOT save money on bread or pasta, but again, yummy.
*You will break about even with cheeses/eggs, and some of them are waaay better than store bought. 
*This is a great spot for tourist shopping if you like open air markets.

I think that actually may sum it up for me. 

I get distracted in Soulard with all the yummies and shineys, and always wish I had brought a much bigger backpack with me. My favorite deal this Saturday had to be 4 huge, beautiful yellow squash for a buck. I practically squealed with delight.

Other random tips:
Bring something to haul produce in. I bring a backpack, but people bring totes and little carts. Strollers work, too.
Please bring reusable cloth bags. C'mon. It isn't that hard, or that big of  deal. 
Park across the street in the bank parking lot. Otherwise you're going to be walking.
Plan extra time to listen to awesome music.
review.author: Sarah D.

review.description: I have been going here every Sat for the past 2 months now and love it. I always have to grab a bloody marry or a $2 16oz draft to get my shopping going. The produce here as far as I have seen is always fresh and the prices are amazing. I would suggest bringing cash because a lot of the vendors do not accept cards. There are multiple booths that sell food for you to eat while shopping and all of them have really good food. The hours here are pretty great but I would suggest going pretty early in the morning to beat out the crowds for the best produce OR a little before they close to get some deals on items. I always buy my bread later in the day because the guy that sells the bread always marks it down in price at the end of the day by a couple of dollars. The meat here in the butcher shop is pretty well priced as well and the quality is outstanding. This is a great place to people watch as well. All kinds of people show up to this market. They do quite a few events here on the weekends as well so you can check out their Facebook page to see what they have going on. This is a really great place. I will continue to go back.
review.author: Emily R.

review.description:
We happened to be in the neighborhood on a Sat afternoon and had yet to check out Soulard Farmers Market.  Being a "Farmers' Market Afficionado," I saw it as my mission to check it out.  I should have read the reviews.
We showed up around 1:30pm and the place was PACKED.  And it wasn't packed with your typical hippie-clothed, broad brim hat-wearing crowd.  It was packed with tourists enjoying the numerous knick-knacks, hot dogs, and Egyptian cotton sheets that you'd not see at my kind of farmers' market.
Sure, call me a farmers' market snob.  I'll own that.  And it'd take a lot to get me back to Soulard Farmers Market.
review.author: Sarah S.

review.description:
This farmer's market is average, but it makes a good trip. It's crowded on Saturday which is when I typically have time to go. Lots of fruits and vegetables, and a mixing of arts & crafts, spices, meats and a couple of concession stands inside. 

It still is fun going to Soulard, saving some money on produce and then spend the savings on a good meal in Soulard somewhere.
review.author: Christopher Z.

review.description: My memories into even young adulthood are excellent of Soulard Farmer's Market.  As a child growing up in the 1960's many watermelon vendor's would give me jobs helping pitch watermelon's off the delivery truck onto the stand.  Good spending money.  The fresh produce and the meat and butcher shops were to die for at this fabulous historic site.
review.author: Bill I.

review.description:
Holy hell, they sell boiled peanuts in various flavors. I bought a pound in each flavor. 

AN awesome farmers' market. They sell a whole lot of produce, meats, and other stuff. We went here on a Saturday morning while visiting STL. It was a fun experience. 

There is a real nice spice store inside and various meat vendors. There are also flower vendors and people selling baked goods. They even have someone selling freshly made mini-donuts on site. 

The one odd thing about this place was a pet store. As Julia W mentions, it was filthy smelling. Lots of bunnies and birds crammed in to little cages. Poor things looked sad and painful. I called the city services and complained about the conditions in the store. There was bird and bunny poop everywhere. Not cool.
review.author: Krsna V.

review.description: Hands down my favorite farmer's market. I love strolling through and checking out everything before finally deciding on what I am going to take home. The vendors let you sample some foods and are usually pretty happy to talk about their product. I like to grab a bloody mary when i go and other times pick up the made-on-the-spot mini donuts. They are so cute!! Overall, this place has everything and more, veggies, meats, spices, clothing & even rugs! If you live in St. Louis and haven't been here...YOU NEED TO GO!!
review.author: Sara R.

review.description: My wife and I had a good time. There are lots of different vendors and a good variety. Prices seemed pretty cheap.
review.author: Corey M.

review.description: One of the  best farmers market ! Only on Fridays n Saturdays ! I had one of the best iced Carmel coffee ! All their staff are friendly   And helpful !:)
review.author: Yanet M.

review.description:
Cheap produce!  

That is really all that needs to be said.
review.author: David Y.

review.description:
If you want to get a true whiff of St. Louis, follow your nose to the historic Soulard Farmers Market.  Gosh, and while you're at it, hunt out the freshly roasted nuts located in the southwest branch of the market place (well that's at least where it was located when I was there).  Their toasty caramelized pecans were delectable and the best I've ever had!  Truly addicting!

Not only that, but there's a HUGE variety of fresh fruits, meats, apparel, sweets, incense, soaps, jewelry and more!  It's not very crowded (and especially not so with tourists) and the quality/prices are better than you could find in any Schnucks or other grocery store.

Now I just have to work on Chicago getting a year-round market!!  And I'm not speaking about Chicago's unique Maxwell Street Market...

Check out the Soulard Market for yourself: Wednesday thru Friday 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. & Saturdays 6:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.
review.author: Richie D.

review.description:
I love waking up early on spring and summer Saturday mornings and heading down to the Soulard Farmer's Market. There's not a whole lot to this open air market; it's basically an awning with vendors underneath it, but I get a great sense of community every time I head to the farmer's market. I like seeing familiar and new faces week after week; happy with their fresh vegetables, fruit, and flowers, thinking of what they're going to do with it all.

I've been coming to the Soulard Farmer's Market for about three years now and I've never had a bad experience with a vendor (sure some are more talkative and friendly than others), bought a bad piece of fruit/vegetation (I'm fairly certain these vendors are meticulous about what they set out), or felt bad when I left. This is a great, leisurely way to spend a Saturday morning, and if you venture out, I'm sure I'll see you there.
review.author: Jennifer H.

review.description:
$5 dozen roses
50 cent cilantro bunches
20 cent avocados
50 cent romaine lettuce heads
50 cents for a pound of you-pick-them button mushrooms
4/$1 bunches of green onion
$1 cherry tomatoes
$1/pound green beans
$1/bunch asparagus
$1 for a 5 lb bag of potatoes
$1 for an eggplant
$1 for 8 green peppers
$1 for 5 zucchini
$1 for 5 mineolas
$2 for a seedless watermelon
50 cents/lb roma tomatoes
$1/bag baby radishes
95 cents strawberries

Amazing deals are to be found here. It's a place that everyone needs to visit at least once...just to see the atmosphere and people. And it's where a savvy shopper can get a lot of fresh produce for almost next to nothing. Definitely stroll around first and get a feel for what is available before you buy. Some produce is fresher than others so be sure to double check before you purchase. And sometimes, as it gets closer to the end of the day, the vendors will go down on the price. Definitely check out the meat market...the weisswurst is pretty good...and the spice shop, which probably has every spice known to man for relatively cheap prices, along with flavorful coffees. And don't forget to get your mini-donuts with your Bloody Mary!
review.author: Cherie O.

review.description: What can you say about the Soulard Farmer's Market? Of course they have delicious fruit, food and good things to buy. That isn't why you go to this place. You go to the Soulard Market because of the history of the area and the building. A place that basically anyone should go to at least once a year to get some fresh fruit which is very inexpensive.
review.author: Nick V.

review.description: A great place for a budget minded shopper who enjoys fresh food! You can get anything from gus` pretzels to fresh loose tea to a live chicken. I love going to the market to help support our local farmers and to get a healthier option of food. It's a lot of fun to go but I suggest get there early on Saturdays because it can get crowded.
review.author: Marie R.

review.description:
After going there for years I stopped going for a number of reasons:

- I discovered most of the produce vendors there are not farmers, they buy their stuff from wholesalers at Produce Row. Not only that, but they buy the produce that's past its prime and that would otherwise end up in Dumpsters.

- I can get fresher, cheaper produce at Aldi's without the crowds, the parking headaches, the bad smells, the drive, and the heat.

- I discovered one of the vendors I trusted routinely added up my order wrong, always in her favor.

- Unlike at stores, you can't choose your produce. The vendors almost always slip a few rotten pieces in the bottom of the bag.

- Even if you've been their customer for years, some vendors are just plain rude and unpleasant. One particularly bad offender is George Simon. Even though he is a sub-deacon at St. Raymond's, he's profane and treats his customers like dirt.
review.author: John E.

review.description: Such a great spot to check out on a weekend. Tons of great seasonal produce and local items from Saint Louis. Best part is the butcher shop. It's one of the best places for pork shoulder and other meats in large quantities in town. Fresh meat, and they cut it right there for you.
review.author: Chip M.

review.description: A must if you live in the St. Louis area. Farm Fresh veggies, meat, pets and cocktails.
review.author: Tony S.

review.description: My husband and I visited to Soulard Farmers market last weekend for the first time, and were blown away. We got there around 10am and had to fight the crowds. Parking was difficult and vendors were really busy. We heard that if you can get there earlier it's much less crowded. We purchased delicious fresh pasta, avocados for $1.00, watermelons for $2.50, HUGE bags of broccoli for $2.50 and more. We will definitely be going back.
review.author: Sarah J.

review.description:
I am such a huge fan of this place.  I was deterred for a while due to some of the low-star reviews some people have given it.  After visiting a few times, I do see why some of the cons were listed, but it still doesn't make me stop yearning to go every weekend! 

It does get crowded, but this doesn't bother me - I actually really enjoy the hustle and bustle.  Adds a nice vibe to the experience.  I agree that it is hard to distinguish local produce from wholesale produce.  But you can always just ask.  I've never had an issue with parking and I've always gone on a Saturday morning...I just park a couple blocks away, south of the market, and walk.

I do have a complaint that some of the produce doesn't look very fresh.  But, there are so many vendors, that I can just walk to another vendor and find the same thing at better quality. 

The produce is SO cheap that sometimes I feel like I should throw in an extra buck or two as to not rip anyone off. 

Dairy and meat vendors are there too, but I haven't tried them.  I'm really not a dairy and meat type of gal, so I probably never will.  But a couple of my friends are really into buying stuff from those vendors because you can find some craaaaazy stuff: rabbit, raccoon, quail, goat, etc.  No thanks...but I hope someone else enjoys them!

One of my favorite vendors sells packaged food, such as wild rice, couscous, steel cut oats, quick oats, dried fruits, etc.  The wild rice is absolutely delicious and has such a great flavor!  I also tried the couscous with cranberries.  It's good too, but has a pretty intense, salty taste.  

I enjoy seeing the random items that are being sold...Cardinal's memorabilia, sunglasses, purses, beautiful flowers, pets, bamboo (I bought some!!), etc.  

You can even buy food to eat while walking around - I have sworn to myself that I will go to the market hungry next time in order to partake in these delicious looking items!  Oh and alcoholic beverages are there too! 

Give this place a chance - even if you don't like it, you're sure to remember it.  There's a reason it's famous!
review.author: Trisha P.

review.description: After several years living here, I decided to get my butt up one early Saturday morning to experience this market.  Boy was I disappointed.  Like previous reviews stated, there was a lack thereof of local produce.  When I think of farmer's market, I think of local produce & not produce from other states &/or countries.  I get that somethings just doesn't grow well here.  As other people have said, get up early to beat the crowds & get the fresh er fresher produce.  This market isn't that big.  There are some good deals (like $17.89 (methinks) a pound on rack of New Zealand lamb from the meat market).  Look closely at the produce or you can get ripped off.  That was my mistake.  Sometimes, it is much better to get some produce at the grocery store or at either Sam's Club or Costco.  Would I come back here, maybe but only for the rack of lamb, maybe a couple of plants &  maybe some dried locally made pasta & some bread.
review.author: Kat V.

review.description:
Man I miss this place.
If the cheap produce isn't enough to draw you in, the people watching will. It's a show. Always has been. 
The crowds don't bother me as much now that I live in New York City (neither does the smell.......) and it is probably the best bang for your buck as far as fresh foods go. Parking is always a nightmare, but seriously, it's worth it. I walked around with my jaw agape at some of the deals. Seriously.
review.author: Lauren L.

review.description:
What a disappointment.

I was all geared up to be in fresh fruit/veggie heaven this a.m. during my family's outing to the Soulard Farmers Market, and came away instead feeling like I just wasted an hour of my day.

Why, you ask? Because it seemed the majority of vendors weren't offering homegrown goods but stuff shipped in from elsewhere. Well, wtf? Okay, I get that it's early in the season, but that's no excuse for such low quality products. I couldn't believe some of the produce they were trying to get people to buy - the garbage can was the only place some of their goods belonged.

In addition, the setup of the market is far from conducive to any sort of crowd - because it's so small it's difficult to walk through and absolutely no air is ventilated through the long hallways. On an 85 degree day, that is NOT the way I want to spend my time.

The one highlight of the trip was our purchase from Baetje Farms - their sign announces fresh goat cheese made weekly, and based on the taste test of their offerings, it was obvious that they know what they're doing. It was some of the best cheese I've ever tasted. We ended up with the cranberry and cinnamon concoction as well as the garlic and chive version. With crackers, it made for a fabulous evening snack. I highly recommend seeking them out if you opt to visit this market - may just be the only highlight of your visit too.
review.author: cassie r.

review.description: The market is just amazing. Makes you realize the quality you are not getting at a big box store.
review.author: John A.

review.description: We went on an overcast Thursday, so it was the opposite of what it might be on a busy Saturday.  It was quiet, abandoned, with only half of the vendors present that would normally be there.  But the smell of fresh fruit and exotic spices filled the air - and the super cheap prices!  Yeah, you should make it out here.
review.author: Stephen H.

review.description:
I struggle writing this review.  I've been here a ton of times and it has so many wonderful things (the meat market and spice shop merit their own reviews).  But, as for the rest of the market...ehhh...

First the pros:

1) Bloody Marys available at multiple locations.  Win.

2) There's another meat vendor that has wicked awesome Canadian bacon.  Seriously, it's incredible.  Next time we go, I'll verify the vendor's name.

3) Pet store - yeah, it stinks at times, but when they have kittens or bunnies in the window, it's nice to stop and see some cute meat, er, animals.

4) Flowers - there's an awesome flower place in there too which a great selection

5) Prices - you will definitely save money on your produce...but....

Cons:

1) Produce - we apparently have the worse luck in the world.  Basically any produce we buy, if not used within two days, ends up going bad.  This includes things from locals and wholesalers.  It has gotten to the level that we buy the meats and spices only here.  Sort of defeats the purpose of a farmers market.

2) Fellow human beings - this is not the place to go if you have in innate hatred of those that have no concept there are others in the world.  Groups of 3-4 people standing in the middle of the aisle chatting and slowing down foot traffic?  Check.  Parents with their uber babymobile clipping your heel?  Check.

3) Counterfeit/knockoff items - I don't give two craps that your purses or sunglasses have the disclaimer that they are "inspired by" a certain designer.  They're effing knockoffs.  Seriously, get this crap out of here.  I would rather have stalls filled with tropical items in February than see one more "Goach" bag.  (And no, my wife didn't make me write this part, I just can't stand seeing it)

There's a bunch of other good things here, but there are enough disappointments that I can't overlook.
review.author: Timothy G.

review.description:
Three-and-a-half pounds of peaches, 4 ears of corn, 1 head of cabbage, 5 lemons, 4 large cucumbers, 3 plums, 1 celery bunch, 2 lbs. sweet potatoes, and 1 lb. carrots = $ 8.50.  Why do I feel like I just "ripped off" some people for their fresh produce with the amount I paid for all of it or did someone just under-price what I got?  I have now fallen in-love with visiting my local ATM and grabbing my reusable bags for produce "bargain" shopping at Soulard!

Came here this past Friday (rather early, might I add) and 50/50 of the stalls were open/closed.  Everyone we encountered was patient enough with my constant changing of mind and insistence of them using my recyclable shopping bags.  I hear shopping is best early in the morning (they publicize opening at 7am) and I suggest going the furthest from your car and working your way back so you're not overwhelmed with all the great deals you got!  I plan to make this a frequent venue for most of my fresh produce needs!
review.author: Liz Z.

review.description: A St. Louis landmark and historic institution that everyone should patronize for fresh fruits and vegetables!
review.author: Amanda H.

review.description: First time here was a rainy, hot Saturday afternoon. It was a few hours before closing and a lot of vendors had packed up, but overall there was still a good crowd. The $4 Bloody Mary's are a must. The selection of produce was ok, I'll be anxious to see what it is like later in the season. I was looking for a good selection of local farmers/vendors and didn't really find it. There were too many people selling fruit and vegetables from California or Mexico. They looked pretty fresh, but I came for local food. The florist in the center had a great selection of boquets and overall the deals on produce were extremely reasonable, so I will definitely be back.
review.author: Mollie N.

review.description: This market is amazing! I went in the afternoon and it was so hot and busy, but it was worth it. I got quite a bit of produce and other local goods. It was all really reasonably priced too. I got the mini donuts and they did not last long at all. There was also a gelato stand and a few local meat markets. I got some bacon and it was thick and flavorful, probably the best bacon I've ever had. I definitely want to go back!
review.author: Jacklyn M.

review.description: Fresh fruits and veggies... supporting small biz. What's not to love?!
review.author: Ann T.

review.description: Bloody Marys and Beignets, couldn't be better!
review.author: Allison C.

review.description:
I've gone here ever since I was a child so I have a bit of nostalgia for the place.  Inside the market there is this really great spice store that sells all sorts of spices, dry mixes, coffees and teas etc....smells wonderful too!
There is also a newer little stand that has jambalaya, red beans and rice chicory coffee, and beignets....yummy!
review.author: Crystal R.

review.description: I love this place. As far as farmer's markets go, it's huge! Plus, it has booze and baby animals - I mean how good can it possibly get?! Go here for the food, the people, and the experience. Parking is available in a lot across the street, but I always nab very close street parking.
review.author: Kylie S.

review.description: Bob's Seafood sells frozen Boudin... apparently some place out in Fenton makes it but I have yet to confirm...
review.author: Allan C.

review.description: I love the soulard market! We wake up at the crack of dawn everyday so to come here around 7:15am on a sat is usually best! Soulard is just cheap produce, i usually do not get anything on ice bc thats the produce that will go bad in 2 days. Each vendor has their own prices but dont be fooled by how cheap it is!!! Inspect it all! This is bargain hunting veggies!!! We only take $20 cash and make it stretch for some fruit but mainly romaine, carrots, fresh cilantro, ginger, etc. Add in $4 bouquet of lillies and a loaf of asiago bread (perfect for grilling bruschetta) my $20 goes pretty far here :) the meats ur not really getting a deal on...nor the fish...yeah just stick to produce here. Do know as the day goes by almost every vendor jacks up their prices so be warned! Otherwise stay out the way and bargain ur veggies!
review.author: Saucy G.

review.description:
Saturday morning....
 The crowds congregate, blend, form... here in St Louis... 9th and Vincent... Soulard. The spawn of the Farmer's market... a convergence, a flickering sepia-past, the holler of old immigrants, the merchants. I stand before the deluge of the crowd passing through tired entrance markers. The day is hot, and the whistle of the open air market hollows through the rows of stands. Her French roots have awoken, alive for the morning, a return to history... glistening... forming. The spice shops echo of the French Quarter... New Orleans... Americana. The colors vivid, penetrating, fruits, vegetables, red, green, yellow, orange, and the low dim of the overhead light flickering in the shade of canopies. The swinging of weight scales all working together like clockwork, feeding the rhythm. Spoken are the languages of merchants, channeling the old roar of immigrants...here they assemble; history is united. 
The crowd pulsates, moving to an urban rhythm, flowing through the aisles like the Big Muddy. Alive are the blues, eminent, I see it in the eyes of the musicians. Ragged they situate, their stories alive again in old rags. 
 I venture to the pasta stands, greeted by an Italian vendor. Her smile a pearly white, her hair, a contrasting onyx. Sweat softly streams about her face, the exchange is made. A flickering memory of old Italia. Her accent, a thick St Louisian. Her story is revealed. The chapters continue, her story, their story...our story.....assemble.... The chattering of old walkers, canes, and baby carriages, navigating their way through the confusion, the energy. 
Lost in the fold I succumb to the end of the route, met by the familiar mold of the current. The arch is visible again. Defiant and silent in the distance it appears in my eyes. The concrete city, jagged, etched by the mammoth highway, and slowly the holler of the farmer's market whispers away. Fading...the energy concludes; dissipating into the soft hours of the afternoon.  And the now the agora is barren till next Saturday, ready to spring fresh...anew........again.
review.author: George N.

review.description: Perfect farmers market..everything u need from livestock to fresh flowers..a stale of St. Louis history
review.author: Osunlade O.

review.description:
WOW. what a massive, massive dissappointment. We were expecting fresh, locally grown produce. But, instead, we found nothing more than a supermarket without air conditioning. Just stall after stall of produce vendors. I'd rather go to Schnucks, at least I can catch up on Britney's latest exploits while I'm waiting in line.

The Wife was even more dissappointed - she pointed out the fruit stickers at every stall we passed. "there's no way pineapple is grown locally. there's no way MANGOS ARE GROWN LOCALLY!" she started to get pretty loud. 

If you're like us, and looking for locally produced produce, meet us at  the Tower Grove Park Farmer's Market.
review.author: mike l.

review.description:
I love markets in general, and this is a pretty nice one.
The bf and I like to step in here to buy a few produce and fruits. You do have to look carefully at the stuff because not all of it is fresh. Also if you're going to buy fruits or veggies from here, you have to consume it fairly quickly since it doesn't last too long.
The prices are great though!

We tried the Tibetan bbq beef skewers they were selling and they were soooo good. We also got the mini donuts, that we watched them make. They were crunchy and perfect! My boyfriend ate 2 polish sausage hot dogs... yes, two.

I just want to go back and eat in the little shops! My only con for this place is the amounts of people always standing in the way of everything. But I guess that's just my misanthropic alter ego talking...
review.author: Amrita R.

review.description:
My budget is seriously thanking me since I started doing the majority of my grocery shopping at Soulard Farmers Market. It's been around a year since I first came to Soulards and I don't see myself stopping anytime soon. Usually Saturdays are my only options to go so my boyfriend and I get some cash, our reusable shopping bags and head over. The parking lot is very useful because although it's not free, you can pay by the hour and they accept credit cards which is pretty sweet. The only time I have ever had a difficult time finding a spot is around 12pm on the Saturdays that it's super nice and everyone is flocking to the farmers market. Once parked we usually hit up the concession stand for a bud light....shopping for veggies while drinking a beer? You got it right  

It gets super busy on Saturdays but I always go in generally knowing what I'm looking for which seems to help calm some of the sense of chaos in the atmosphere and allow me to enjoy perusing to find the best deal and highest quality items. You will find a wide range of prices and quality so you will be the happiest if you are able to take the time to browse and the more I go the more I remember specific stands that provide the highest quality. My favorite farmers market moment was when I got 5 pounds of potatoes for $1. I LOVE potatoes...potato salad, mashed potatoes, baked potatoes, potato soup...you name it and I couldn't believe I got such a good deal. I almost felt like I was robbing them of their product. I am also usually able to find a good deal on romaine lettuce, strawberries, onions, bananas, etc. Besides those basics, I always have to visit the mushroom man. He sells the best, most flavorful organic shitake mushrooms I have ever had. I am seriously addicted. My visit is never complete without visiting the meat stand, their meat prices are outstanding and the bacon is probably some of the best I have ever had in my life. Best advice I would have is to not buy from the first stand you see but instead take a little bit of time and find the best products...also if you take the time to go out there, do yourself a favor and walk over to Bogarts afterwards for some lunch after shopping. Makes for an awesome afternoon.
review.author: Becca L.

review.description:
I moved to St. Louis a few weeks ago and this place has quickly become one of my favorite parts of the city. The produce, while questionable on occasion, is CHEAP. There's a great selection of fruits, vegetables, meats, bread, cheese, herbs, and even some random bananas and mangoes that clearly weren't grown anywhere near Missouri.

Pros:
-cheap
-friendly vendors
-fun to shop around
-fantastic people watching
-great place to pick up lunch (and beers, what?)

Cons:
-hot as HADES. Go early. 
-I wish it was a little easier to pick out the homegrown vendors.
review.author: Lisa D.

review.description: Great place to stroll around. I have been going here all my life, now i can take my kids.  If you park in the main parking lot and walk in the front door the little concession place is great!  Great food, clean and pretty cheap!
review.author: Cory S.

review.description: Good amount of fresh produce selection. Seafood, meat, and poultry are a little bit cheaper than your local grocery stores. The experience is fun especially if you go there in the morning. Good snack food here and there while you're browsing around. Try those little donuts inside the market (forgot what it's called)  and it is really delicious. I am not sure because we haven't tried but I'm pretty sure you can negotiate the prices on just about any meat and vegetables they offer especially if you buy in bulk. Hope this helps. Bring cash as their ATM sometimes does not work plus it gives you more bargaining power. Overall fun experience.
review.author: Elgene C.

review.description:
Man, this place is old.  As in, it's been around since the mid-1800s.  History alone makes Soulard Farmers Market a very cool place indeed (not to mention that the land on which it sits was donated by a woman named Julia, and we ALL know how cool Julias are).

I visited the market on a Friday morning and am reserving further judgment for a weekend visit when the stalls are apparently all full.  That's not to say there weren't plenty of options on a weekday--fresh produce, herbs and flowers abound in the outdoor stalls, while the indoor portion of the market houses a lovely spice shop (it also sells artisanal cheeses and some meats), a bakery, a few butchers (some even had boudin, which I rarely see outside of Louisiana) and a fish stall that I hear is totally phenomenal.  I'm looking forward to visiting the fish guy the next time we're in town.

All the produce we bought for dinner that night was wonderful and I liked the old-school feel to the market.  One thing grossed me out, though--there's this one stall that's pretty out of the way (thank goodness) and I guess it's a pet store.  It has loads of bunnies that I think were crammed a bit too close together and pigeons for sale for $5.50.  I thought I'd see what else they had, but it smelled so strongly of dirty zoo that I had to pass it by quickly.  Yucko.  Skip the weirdo pet store and stick with the spice shop.  It smells MUCH better.
review.author: Julia W.

review.description: I went on a Friday for less of a crowd, no shops were open except for meats and spices. The produce was looking like a lot of overpriced second quality buys. Walk the whole line looking at the price and quality of any goods that you want to buy. If I lived next door I don't think that I would buy much produce here. The spice shop was a five star shop. I made several well priced buys here. Meat market shop enclosed looked and smelled like a very good butcher shop. This place could use a fresh fish market. It is really hard to find fresh fish in the St. Louis area and I think a Market here with fresh fish would do well. Don't get your hopes up when you come here and make sure that your parked LEGAL.
review.author: Gary K.

review.description: I wish CAlifornia had a farmer's market like this! Too cool. ;)
review.author: Justin K.

review.description:
We're going to go ahead and chalk this up as a 3.5 star review (I round up). There's much to love at Soulard Market...be warned though, if you hate crowds and noise, just don't go. 
I've read a few of the other reviews and while I agree with some of the comments regarding local produce, I do have some things to say to that. My wife and I did notice this past Saturday that there are quite a few vendors selling wholesale-bought produce, yes...BUT, there are those farmers in the rough who actually bring you their goods straight from the farm and sell it to you cheap, you just have to be on the look-out. That one point makes things hard though, I wish the farmers that are local and grow their own stuff would advertise that a little better...there was only one stall that actually had a huge banner saying 'locavores welcome!' and they backed it up with awesome produce. Otherwise, you have to just use some common sense. Usually, if there's a sticker on the fruit, it's not local. Also, there's always the tried and true method of just ASKING where they get their produce. What? Talk to people? Oh man...what a concept. Another note...we live in the midwest. Shocker, I know...but we do. With that, that means that we have certain produce that is local, and some that just cannot be. Pineapple? Not grown here. Neither is mango. And nope...cherries aren't either. So I say, while you're there buying the locally grown stuff...go ahead and pick up the stuff that you will NEVER find grown locally...and don't complain about it, because it's one stop shopping. Be smart...some things you have to buy shipped in, it's just where we live. 
We were able to buy locally and for the whole week for just under $20...which is amazing. Soulard also sells a ton of meat, eggs, dairy, cheese...but we didn't really hit that up so I can't comment. Though, we had the mini-doughnuts which were like tiny funnel cakes (and made in a tiny fryer!!). We've also enjoyed the bloody mary/beignet combo on the west side of the market...that was a great day. :) 
The market is a vibrant part of St. Louis...both for shopping and culture. Music playing, food cooking, people buying their groceries for the week. We need Soulard...ST. Louis needs Soulard...go to Soulard even if it's just to buy some mini doughnuts.
review.author: Steve O.

review.description:
A unique experience in St. Louis, and a great place to find locally-produced goods.

Also, though, a great place to experience obnoxious crowds and find a lot of produce and merchandise that's no different than anywhere else; I don't find the myriad of fruits and vegetables from around the world that were purchased at Produce Row that morning to be any more tasty purchased here than from a big box retailer.  And how many mass-produced baseball caps does one need?

But there's a guy that trades only in mushrooms, many local.  And locally-produced cheese and bakes goods.  A must-see for locals, but not for tourists from other cities.
review.author: Hans G.

review.description: The Farmers market is obviously one of our favorite places to (people watch) get produce! There is always a wide variety of vendors, produce, and prices! The one thing that they do not have on the KC farmers market is a spice stand. They do however have some great garlic that is already peeled and ready for cooking! What we can get at the grocery store for $30 doesn't even amount to what we can get at the Farmers Market. Because these veggies are not treated with anything I do notice that they do go bad sooner than normal veggies from the store would but thankfully we go through them very fast. This is a great place to wheel and deal for some good food. Make sure you go early on Saturday before all of the good stuff is gone but be ready for a large crowd by 10:30 or sooner! There are also stands that offer a snack along the way... Mini donuts, toated ravs, bloody marys, pastrys, and even beef jerkey!
review.author: Amanda C.

review.description:
The Soulard Farmer's Market is a staple of St. Louis. Every single time that I have been there, it is always a fun experience. Not only is the being there pleasurable with the sites, sounds, and texture of everything in the market.

At the Soulard Farmer's Market you can find just about anything that you would think of. They have different kinds of meats, from opossum; yes opossum, to your normal cuts of chicken and beef. Then there is what I usually go for which would be the fresh vegetables that they have there.

The nice thing about going to Soulard Farmer's Market is the fact that you help support local farmers, so it is good to give back to the community.
review.author: Aaron J.

review.description:
In St. Louis, budweiser flows like tap water.  Bud is served everywhere, even at this farmer's market.  The beer cost only $2 and definitely altered the way I look at produce.  Eggplants look really strange when you're wearing bear goggles.

I don't go to farmers' markets that much, but I noticed that this place had a lot of homegrown products.  I bought some amish applebutter (taken from me at the airport - more than 3 oz. bottle) and some amish cookies.  Who knew there were amish people in St. Louis.  I didn't until I went to this market.  

Also, we went on a Saturday morning and the place wasn't that crowded.  That's a good thing.  Fewer people fighting over those $2 beers.

I wish the SF farmer's market was a little more like this place.
review.author: Robson S.

review.description: Strawberries, people - Scharf's has lovely fresh strawberries right now.  Get over there next weekend and get yourself a flat.  :-)
review.author: Rozebud S.

review.description:
Bigger than the farmer's market in my hometown in Phoenix, but may actually have less number of farmers.  Reminds me more of open air public markets I've been to in Asia.  More of a bunch of mom and pop type grocers rather than farmers.

I'd return for the tastiest pork rinds ever... a clean, non greasy crunch ...more crispy than potato chips...lighter than pop corn... and came in great flavors like mustard and salt &
review.author: Helen Y.

review.description:
The first thing I do when I go to the Farmer's Market is hit up the bakery for an "elephant ear" pastry. That gets me started.

It's a haven for a St. Louis foodie: fresh produce at a low cost, good cheeses at the Amish stand, a decent spice stand, and a meat/fish stand that's good (but a little pricey). I try to get my bacon here, though.

Oh yeah, I bought a goldfish here once, and it lasted for quite a bit. Speaking of that, you can get really lost in buying and buying more food, since it's so cheap. I suggest bringing a canvas bag or something to carry it all. Those plastic bags the stands offer just don't cut it. 

I just realized you can haggle at some kiosks. That gives me a whole new reason to visit the Farmer's Market over and over.
review.author: Nowell G.

review.description: You just never know what you will find here. You can get produce dirt cheap here, but the key is walking thru the whole place a couple times before you start buying things. You can usually find it cheaper somewhere else. First and foremost don't let the vendors pick your stuff. Often they put their best stuff out on display and when they lure you in then they throw in their old stuff when they bag it. Also the cheap thing is good, but when I take the time to cook, its a lot of effort so I go for QUALITY. That is what makes this place so great. Go early, go early, go early. Especially on Saturday. Take a cart, or a box, and maybe a cooler with ice if you're really stocking up.  I got a Gus' pretzel with a bratwurst inside of it. Very tasty. I also really like the bloody Mary's at the northeast wing comes with a green bean, celery, lime, olive, and some cajun spice thats right on. I saw a child there horrified by the sight of a fish being chopped. That poor kid. There is also a"petstore" there. And the people that just sell chicken and eggs have the best poultry anywhere.
review.author: Chris K.

review.description: Few things make me hotter than fresh fruit and produce. When we arrived at the market the first stop was for a hot pretzel and an Irish coffee, which turned out to be more Irish than coffee, and I am really good with that. As we walked around the market there were a few things that kept coming up, the fruit and vegetables were outstanding and the fresh made mini donuts are to die for...I'm serious they are high in sugar and made in boiling fat so they will kill you, but they are worth it. All of the vendors are really nice and you can find everything from plums to collard greens. There are so many little shops and stands scattered throughout the market that every time you go it is an adventure. The hot links and the Andouille sausage from the shop that had Coon We also grabbed a  german garlic dog on the way out and holy cow it was good, a little brown mustard a little ketchup it was like a mothers kiss.....if your mother was a spicy German collection of ground meats.
review.author: Travis B.

review.description:
Peoples' reviews show they're more knowledgeable about farmers' markets, but sometimes they're not paying attention at Soulard.  There are definitely local farmers  - who offer wonderfully fresh produce and herbs, including more unusual ones like bay leaves, fennel, and Japanese spinach (tatsoi?) in season - also the local goat cheesemaker (the Provencal variety is fabulous!); poultry, egg and butter sellers; the mushroom man, who arranges his offerings like still lifes; pastas in a great variety of flavors, with tasty recipes attached to the bag; Kaldi's coffees; Black Bear Bakery, a local coop.  

Of course some distributors sell produce they got at the wholesale market, especially when local produce is not in season.  Take advantage of what's there.
review.author: Linda E.

review.description: fresh pasta, fresh meat, fresh produce, fresh fresh fresh--  its the only thing that gets me out of bed on a saturday morning (except maybe cartoons!)
review.author: Paul D.

review.description: My first experience here was when I was 6yrs old. It was a weekly trip I took with my grandparents. Amazing how we lose connections with the things of our past as we grow old. I went here Sat. morning for the 1st time in many years. Not much has changed...brought back many memories. I would suggest getting there about 7am-8am to get really good stuff but don't buy from the first vendor you meet...walk through and look at all the produce because sometimes you might find it a little cheaper down the line. There is an awesome spice house on the inside that is open year round, they also sell a variety of flavored coffee beans you can have ground for that fresh coffee smell. :) ....there is also a meat market on the inside as well. They even sell beef ribs! Only downside I have with this place....they are not open on Sundays.....so get up early on Sat. and take a trip to Soulard. If you are a fan of pork rinds,,, there is a vendor setup in the front of the market making fresh, fried pork rinds with a variety of flavors...$3.00 a bag for you fans of this snack food. Hey guys..... or gals....you can buy fresh flowers really cheap here also....$5 for a bouquet of roses!
review.author: Lisa M.

review.description: place is awsome, tips: for produce deals go after 330 on saturday, always choose your own produce, farmer with live game in NE hallway has best pork products in Mo., if you are into exotic meats you'll have a number of option
review.author: Adam M.

review.description: I give it all the stars I can for the memories. My father loved to take us shopping there -- that was a long time ago. He really enjoyed talking to the vendors, who were small businessmen who bought and sold produce. I don't think it was ever a true farmers' market where the producers sold their own goods. Some day maybe I'll get back and visit it.
review.author: Mae S.
